questions.question: We went out ………………….. the rain.
questions.description: In spite of is the correct expression. It is a preposition. Because is a conjunction.

questions.question: There is a school ..................... my house.
questions.description: You can't possibly have a school in front of your house. To express the idea 'on the other side of the road', we use opposite.

questions.question: If it ..................... for his wife’s money, he would never be a film producer.
questions.description: In the second conditional both wasn't and weren't are possible with singular subjects.

questions.question: ……………….. I realized what you intended, I wouldn’t have permitted this.
questions.description: The correct expression is 'If I had realized what you intended,...'

questions.question: Had we not cancelled our tickets, we .....................…… in the accident.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use would have + past participle form of the verb to express hypothetical ideas.

questions.question: There is little ...................... good evidence for flying saucers.
I would have been in bad trouble, if you .....................…… me.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use would have + past participle in the main clause and past perfect tense in the if-clause.

questions.question: You ......................... better turn that music down before your dad gets angry.
Take your coat and pass me ......................
questions.description: My is a possessive adjective and mine is a possessive pronoun. My is used before a noun. Mine is used alone.

questions.question: This house ................................. in
questions.description: We need a passive form here because the subject is not the doer of the action.
